prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author of the situation is in the wrong. The scenario is about a couple living together where the author (a guy) pays all the bills because his girlfriend only works part-time. The issue arose when he asked her to pay for a $40 takeout because he left his wallet, and she reacted negatively.

First, I need to consider the dynamics of their relationship. The guy has been covering all expenses, which he didn't mind until this incident. The key points here are communication, expectations, and fairness. 

The author is upset because the girlfriend's reaction was "ugly" and "put out." He feels that even though she earns less, she should start contributing, even a little, for the sake of principle. 

Now, to assess if the author is in the wrong. One angle is that he's never been in this situation before, so maybe the girlfriend felt it was a first-time request, and her reaction was due to surprise or not expecting to have to pay. Maybe she didn't realize he wanted her to contribute more. On the other hand, the author is making a big deal out of a small incident, which could be seen as overreacting. 

Also, considering that the girlfriend only works part-time, expecting her to start paying bills might be a sudden shift. The author might have never discussed financial responsibilities before, so she didn't know to expect it. His frustration is understandable, but holding a single incident to demand her to start paying could be unfair if there was no prior discussion. 

In relationships, communication is key. If the author never mentioned wanting her to contribute, then he's putting pressure on her without prior agreement. The girlfriend's reaction might have been due to the suddenness of the request rather than a lack of willingness to help. So, the author might be in the wrong for not discussing this before and using a small incident as a catalyst for a larger change without talking it over. 

Alternatively, if the author felt it was time for her to contribute and the incident was the trigger, maybe he's justified in wanting her to start. But since it's based on a single incident, it could be seen as petty. The value of the takeout is low, so her reaction might have been disproportionate, but the author's response could also be disproportionate in making her pay all bills because of it. 

So, the answer might depend on whether the author addressed the issue calmly and communicated his expectations before the incident, which he didn't. Therefore, the author could be in the wrong for not having that conversation earlier and using a minor event to enforce a significant change without discussing it first.
